 THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA SOCIAL REFORM AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROJECT CREDIT AND PROJECT SUMMARY Borrower: The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia Amount: SDR 9.0 Million (US$ 14.0 million equivalent) Terms: 10 years grace and 35 years maturity Project Objectives: The success of Macedonia's economic reform program will depend upon whether the Borrower can deal effectively with the social dimensions of reform. The objective of the proposed Social Reform and Technical Assistance Project is to support the Borrower's reform program by: (a) facilitating the restructuring of socially owned enterprises through actions to reduce the individual and community impacts of worker dislocation, (b) improving the delivery of social benefits and the collection of payroll contributions for social benefits, (c) improving public awareness of the rationale for reform policies, and (d) supporting the continuing implementation of the enterprise restructuring program. Project Description: The project will be implemented over four years by the Agency for the Transformation of Enterprises with Social Capital (Privatization Agency) in cooperation with the Ministry of Labor and Social Policy (MOLSP), the State Statistical Bureau, and the Ministry of Finance (MOF). Project cost is estimated at US$ 17.1 million equivalent including contingencies, local taxes and duties. The cost includes consulting services, fellowships and training, furniture, equipment and materials, vehicles, financial resources for a Labor Redeployment Fund, and incremental operating costs generated by the investments. The project comprises four components: a. Labor Redeployment (US$ 10.9 million). This component will support the redeployment of labor in communities affected by large-scale enterprise restructuring by: (i) analyzing the labor requirements of socially-owned enterprises (SOEs) which are undergoing restructuring or privatization, (ii) providing pre-layoff adjustment services to workers in SOEs scheduled for downsizing or liquidation, (iii) providing post-layoff services' to the displaced workers, through a Labor Redeployment Fund, to accelerate their return to productive employment, (iv) strengthening Employment Bureau services for job seekers, and (v) establishing a Project Coordination Unit (PCU) to support overall project implementation. i/ These include programs for employment counseling and job placement, relocation, retraining, small business assistance, and local economic development planning, but exclude severance payments which are financed separately through the Government's Special Restructuring Program.
 ii b. Public Information Program (US$ 1.4 million). This component will support the development of public media information programs to build public support for the country's economic reform program. It will do this by: (i) creating a Media Coordinating Unit in the Privatization Agency to oversee the public information program, (ii) conducting surveys to assess public knowledge and opinion on economic reform issues to guide the development of an effective public information program, and (iii) developing and carrying out a public media program to inform the public of the rationale for specific reform measures. c. Social Benefit Programs (US$ 2.4 million). This component will help develop more equitable, efficient, and financially sustainable social benefit programs by: (i) developing objective poverty criteria as a basis for targeting social assistance, (ii) developing actuarially-based pension planning, and (iii) improving payroll tax collection by improving business registration procedures and strengthening audit and enforcement controls. d. Enterprise Restructuring Technical Assistance (US$ 2.4 million). This component would provide technical assistance to: (i) establish a Trustee Unit at the Privatization Agency to manage enterprise restructuring, (ii) accelerate privatization of viable SOEs and liquidation of non-viable SOEs, (iii) impose stringent financial controls on external resources provided to enterprises from the state budget or the banking system, and (iv) identify the post-privatization technical assistance needs of SOEs. Benefits: The major benefit expected from the proposed project would be to foster public acceptance of the country's economic reform program, thus helping ensure the sustainability of the reform program. In addition, labor redeployment activities supported by the project would help reduce public budgetary outlays and increase national output by moving workers from jobs where they are not productive, and receive public subsidies, to jobs where they are more productive. The employment effect of some labor redeployment programns (i.e. training) may be reduced to some extent if workers who benefit from the programs displace other workers. However, even in these cases, the programs should contribute to increased productivity. The project would also help restore long-run fiscal balance by improving tax collections and by establishing a more equitable, efficient, and affordable basis for pensions and social assistance. Risks: The principal risk associated with the proposed project is that a failure to impose a hard budget constraint could permit further delays in real restructuring of the largest loss-making enterprises, including needed labor shedding, thereby undermining the basis for the project. The proposed FESAC and follow-up policy oversight expected under subsequent operations would reduce this risk to an acceptable level. Moreover, because the project is viewed by Borrower authorities as a pre-requisite to effective enterprise reform, the project itself would help to mitigate this risk. However, in the event that there are substantial delays or changes in the FESAC, that affect the special restructuring program, the configuration of the project would need to be reconsidered because is it specifically designed to support the special restructuring program. Finally, the implementation capacity of some of the agencies involved is weak. The project addresses this issue by providing technical assistance and requiring the agencies to add small numbers of staff to support project implementation.

 THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA SOCIAL REFORM AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROJECT I. INTRODUCTION 1.1 In this fourth year of political independence, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia faces a particularly difficult challenge: the transformation to a market economy in a situation of extraordinary economic isolation. In parallel with the loss of markets in the former Soviet bloc after 1989, the disintegration of Yugoslavia profoundly changed the environment in which the enterprise sector operated. United Nations sanctions against Serbia and Montenegro brought about a loss of the country's largest export market. In addition, the closure of the border with Greece, its main trade route to the sea, limited access to alternative markets and increased the cost of imported goods. As a result of these external events, gross social product (GSP)' has declined to less than half its 1989 level, and unemployment has risen to approximately 30 percent of the labor force.2 1.2 In 1992, the Borrower embarked on a stabilization and economic reform program, which includes privatization of socially-owned enterprises (SOEs). In spite of the difficulties associated with the collapse of external markets and imposed economic isolation, the Borrower remains committed to this program. Under the first Economic Recovery Loan (ERL 1),3 the Borrower adopted a new privatization law, and established the Agency for Privatization of Enterprises with Social Capital (Privatization Agency) to assist enterprises in preparing restructuring plans and to oversee the privatization of SOEs. As part of its Special Restructuring Program, the Privatization Agency has identified 25 enterprises to be restructured or privatized on a priority basis. These 25 enterprises4 account for about four-fifths of losses in the enterprise sector in 1993 and currently employ 56,700 workers -- about 13 percent of formal employment in the country. A parallel Financial and Enterprise Sector Adjustment Credit (FESAC) will support policy reform in the enterprise, banking and social sectors. Policy goals to be supported in the social sectors include: (a) facilitating the transfer of labor from SOEs to new employment opportunities, (b) reforming the social assistance system in an effort to make it sustainable and to improve employment incentives, and (c) assisting the Pension Fund to be financially self sufficient. 1.3 While the FESAC establishes an appropriate policy setting for the enterprise restructuring program, specific investments will be needed in several areas to implement the program. 1/ Gross Social Product is defined as the sum of national income and depreciation of the capital stock, where national income is the value added of goods produced in the 'productive sector' (e.g. agriculture, manufacturing, etc). GSP, unlike GDP, (i) does not include value added from services, and (ii) does not deduct the costs of services in calculating the value added of goods produced in the economy. 2/ In July 1994, 195,000 individuals out of an active labor force of about 640,000 were registered as unemployed at the National Employment Bureau. 3/ Loan 3703-MK and Credit 2564-MK, both approved on February 8, 1994. 4/ This includes 20 industrial enterprises and 3 agro-enterprises, plus one power utility and one railway.

Second, public support for the transition is threatened by rising unemployment, deteriorating living conditions, uncertainty about the political and economic future, and public confusion about the rationale for specific reform policies. Public support for reform will require better public awareness of the reasons why the Borrower is pursuing specific reform policies.  3 II. SECTORAL BACKGROUND A. Restructuring Program for Socially-owned Enterprises 2.1 The socially owned and mixed ownership sector is comprised of 1,856 enterprises8 employing 324,000 workers (53 percent of all formal sector employees), primarily in the trade, construction, agricultural, and textile sectors.9 Overstaffing and redundancy are pervasive in these enterprises. For example, an August 1994 survey of 25 large SOEs indicates that managers expect at least one-third of their workers to be laid off during restructuring. 2.2 The former Yugoslavia introduced legislation in 1989 for the transformation of social ownership (the Law on Social Capital). However, implementation was not well regulated and was accompanied by abuses. As a consequence, the Borrower stopped all privatization and introduced the Law for Transformation of Socially-Owned Enterprises in June 1993 (the Privatization Law). Under the law, the Borrower targeted 1,468 enterprises for privatization; about half are socially owned and half are mixed ownership enterprises. One hundred are large; 299 are medium; and 1,069 are small.'" In total, they represent 79 percent of all socially owned and mixed ownership enterprises, 78 percent of SOE employment, and 53 percent of SOE assets. Eventually, most of the other SOEs must also be privatized, with similar labor redeployment consequences. 2.3 At the same time, the private sector is making a growing contribution to economic activity. At the end of February 1994, approximately 17,000 private sector enterprises were active in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The number of registered self-employed persons (and their employees) increased from 15,219 in 1990 to 36,182 in 1993." While the majority of private sector companies operate in services and trade, socially owned and mixed enterprises are concentrated in production of iron and steel, non-ferrous metals, textiles, footwear and tobacco. 2.4 While many large enterprises have stopped paying wages with the collapse of product markets, they have generally not dismissed any of their redundant workers, many of whom continue 8/ The Privatization Agency uses a figure of 1,856 enterprises -- 1,019 socially owned and 837 mixed ownership -- and does not count subsidiaries as separate enterprises. The retention of redundant labor is inefficient because it delays the reallocation of labor to alternative productive employment, thus lowering labor productivity, increasing enterprise losses, and impeding enterprise restructuring. While the retention of redundant labor may reflect the unwillingness of enterprise managers to inflict higher rates of unemployment on their communities, it may also represent a rational response to prevailing employment and social benefit policies. For example, layoffs are deterred by laws requiring employers to give six months notice and provide up to 12 months of severance pay to dismissed workers (in addition to back wages), as well as by a provision that poor households headed by an employed worker receive higher social assistance benefits than equally poor households whose head is not employed. 2.5 The Borrower has established a Special Restructuring Program (SRP) to deal with 25 large politically sensitive loss-making enterprises which include 20 industrial and 3 agro-enterprises, plus the national railways and the national electric power utility. These enterprises represent about 10 percent of formal sector employment. With the help of bilateral consultants, diagnostic studies have already been carried out for each of the enterprises and loss-reduction plans have been adopted, including, where applicable, general plans for large-scale labor shedding. 2.6 Under the Special Restructuring Program and the FESAC, the Borrower will adopt a number of measures to strengthen enterprise management and impose financial discipline. The 23 industrial and agro-enterprises will be given up to one year to demonstrate that they can generate a positive operating cash flow (before debt service payments). During this time, they will benefit from a moratorium on debt service payments to banks, but they will be forced to run on a cash basis and will not be permitted to increase their arrears to creditors. They will also have no further access to bank credits for either investments or general working capital requirements. However, on an exceptional basis, they will be able to obtain self-liquidating trade credits if these are needed in order to fill specific firm and profitable orders from creditworthy customers. Limited amounts of funds from the budget will be made available to cover temporary cash shortages for working capital. Enterprises which cannot come forward with self-financing business plans (including self-liquidating credits) will be subjected to further cost cutting/downsizing measures or liquidation. Enterprises which succeed in operating on a positive cash flow basis will be eligible for financial restructuring, including debt to equity swaps. The two utilities will be restructured with a focus on improving cost- efficiency, reducing excess labor costs, and dispensing with non-core activities (e.g., guest houses) as an initial step in a long-term rationalization of their activities. It is the Borrower's intention that all of the 23 industrial and agro-enterprises will either have undergone or have entered the process of privatization or liquidation by the completion of the Special Reform Program. 2.7 To ensure that the rules of the SRP are followed and that cost-reduction plans are implemented, the enterprises will be placed in the receivership of a Trustee Unit reporting to a special interninisterial committee, chaired by the Minister of Economy, located at the Privatization Agency, and supported by a team of sectoral advisers and other support staff. The Trustee will be vested with the full rights of ownership of the enterprises, with full legal and fiduciary powers -- including the power to remove and replace non-performing enterprise managers and to control the cash flow of enterprises. The Privatization Agency has obtained some expertise from several bilateral donors (including Japan and the USA) plus assistance from volunteer agencies to help establish the Trustee Unit and to provide assistance, including shadow managers, to SOEs. However, during appraisal, the Borrower requested that additional financing for technical assistance be added to the Social Reform

Labor RcdeDlovment 2.8 Labor redeployment has three distinct and mutually reinforcing phases. First, an analysis needs to be carried out to define the labor and social assets to be divested during enterprise restructuring. Second, pre-layoff assistance needs to be provided within the respective enterprises to advise workers of alternative income support and employment options. Third, post-layoff services need to be provided to displaced workers, based on the demand identified during the pre-layoff phase. The status of labor redeployment under these three phases in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is described below. 2.9 Analysis of Enterprise Labor Requirements. The development of revised labor force requirements at the enterprise level is one of the first steps that should be taken in the process of enterprise restructuring. This analysis should occur in parallel with the development of revised financial and business plans for the SOEs because excess labor is one of the key issues that must be addressed in developing these plans. In the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, determining the labor requirements for individual enterprises has been hindered by a lack of information regarding the qualifications, skills and characteristics of workers and the qualifications and skill profiles that are needed by the enterprise. This deficiency is exacerbated by the reluctance of SOE managers to deal with the concept of layoffs and redeployment, in part because they lack the knowledge and resources to assist displaced workers. 2.10 At this first stage of analysis, revised labor force specifications provide general information about the number of workers affected by restructuring, including their skill levels and demographic characteristics. Existing and optimal staffing levels are compared, based on revised financial and business plans, but specific workers to be affected are not yet identified. The initial enterprise-level analysis would include current labor force profiles, as well as information on the divestiture of social infrastructure. While SOEs in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia do not generally provide housing, schools, or clinics for their employees, other social assets -- including farms, vacation villages, hotels, and shops -- are candidates for privatization. 2.11 Pre-lavoff assistance. Once a formal decision is made to restructure an enterprise, individual redundant workers must be identified and given advance notice. Immediate pre-layoff assistance should be provided at the enterprise level, which will serve to reduce labor-management conflicts and social tensions, as well as communicate valuable information concerning post-layoff options and services. Pre-layoff assistance should include information about alternative employment opportunities within the enterprise, employment opportunities outside the enterprise, eligibility for income support programs, and the purpose and availability of active labor market programs, such as small business assistance, public works opportunities, and retraining, all aimed at accelerating the return of displaced workers to productive employment. 2.12 At present, no public or private group provides systematic assistance prior to layoffs. SOEs have managed labor force adjustments through "soft reductions," including the use of voluntary retirement, "forced holidays", laying off of problem employees, and provision of severance pay.
 6 International experience'2 indicates, however, that successful labor force adjustment programs should distribute the responsibility for redeploying workers among the State and other social partners, including unions, enterprises, and the communities. These techniques are most effective when assistance is provided during the period of advance notice, prior to actual layoff. 2.13 Post-layoff services. The state's interest in providing post-layoff services is to facilitate the transition to alternative productive employment and reduce pressure on the public budget. After layoffs occur, workers will adjust to their new situation in a variety of ways. Some workers will find other jobs rapidly, while others may decide to exit the labor market, retiring or staying at home with their families. Many laid-off workers are likely to apply for income support payments, such as unemployment insurance and social assistance. Some may also request and benefit from in-depth counseling and employment services to help them locate alternative employment, or from public works employment. Displaced workers whose skills are not in demand may benefit from retraining. Relocation assistance may be useful if jobs are more plentiful in other localities. Development of small businesses may also be a viable alternative for some displaced workers. 2.14 In the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, the National Employment Bureau, which operates 30 local employment bureaus, is the public agency charged with providing assistance to the unemployed, particularly through the administration of unemployment benefits. (See Annex III for information about the configuration of local offices.) The Employment Bureau maintains a job vacancy registry, matches job seekers with job vacancies, administers the unemployment benefit program and provides a limited number of other services for the unemployed. It facilitates only limited re-training for the unemployed, contracting through existing training institutions. About 800 (0.4 percent) people were re-trained in 1994 -- a figure that is considerably lower than the 5 to 10 percent of labor force retraining found in many OECD and CEE countries. Employment Bureau staff are primarily occupied with processing unemployment benefits, and have little time to help the unemployed find or prepare themselves for new jobs."3 2.15 The Employment Bureau currently lacks the financial and human resources to improve or expand on existing services. It lacks the trained staff and appropriate materials required to offer up-to-date job placement and counseling services, or to organize retraining and other active labor market programs. Similarly, resources are not available to offer pre-layoff, in-plant services, nor to organize a broader array of post-layoff services in communities affected by large-scale layoffs. Furthermore, the staff to client ratio at the Employment Bureau, at 1 to 525, is considerably less than the 1 to 100 ratio commonly found in OECD countries, where labor redeployment services reflect the needs of a market economy. 14 12/ Examples include the Canadian Industrial Adjustment Service, the Treuhaund in Eastern Germany, and British Coal. 13/ The Bureau does provide a job vacancy registry. The ratio of vacancies to job seekers is currently around I to 20. However, this ratio, the unemployment rate, and the staff-to-client ratio should be interpreted with caution. A large share of "job-seekers' have been registered for many years and may either be working, have other sources of income, or have left the labor market. For example, in 1992, about half of those on the unemployment rolls had been registered for over three years. 14/ E.g., I to 9 in Sweden, 1 to 120 in Portugal, and I to 375 in Turkey (which does not have an unemployment benefit system to administer).
 7 2.16 In summary, the need for labor redeployment services is accentuated by the structural changes in employment that will result from changing patterns of ownership, changes in the size and sectoral distribution of employment, and by the increased emphasis on SOE productivity. Since enterprise restructuring can affect many workers at once, labor redeployment assistance should be directly linked to the privatization process and tailored to sectoral and geographic circumstances. Enterprises need to analyze the impact of restructuring on their labor force, provide pre-layoff assistance in consultation with community and labor representatives, and organize post-layoff services for displaced workers, using local service providers. C. Public Information 2.17 The human impact of structural reform in transition economies is prone to create public dissatisfaction, nostalgia for the previous system, and the sentiment that the market economy is responsible for unfulfilled expectations of the transition. This situation in turn, tends to erode public support for economic reforms, which further reduces their chances of success. These trends are evident in several former planned economies -- including Poland, Hungary, Bulgaria, and Russia, where communist or socialist parties have made strong showings in recent elections. Should public opinion change in a similar direction in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, the Borrower's economic reform program could face insurmountable opposition. 2.18 Little information is currently available on public attitudes towards the emerging market economy and the Borrower's continuing program of structural economic change. Until recently, no Ministry has been fully cognizant of the need to monitor and inform public opinion, although, in theory, the Ministry of Information might have been expected to perform this function. That Ministry has not functioned effectively for some time, however, having no top-level Ministerial appointment and no clear statement of mission. 2.19 The Privatization Agency, in recognizing the need for effective, interactive public communication in the context of the privatization program, has taken the lead in developing a Public Information Campaign. As a first step, the Agency has engaged a private firm to create an advertising campaign aimed at improving public understanding of the enterprise privatization program. Subsequent steps taken by the Privatization Agency include employing an international public relations expert, and providing for training of the Director of the Agency's Public Relations Center at a six-week external training program. 15 2.20 Mass media campaigns have played an important role worldwide in social and political reforms undertaken by governmental and international organizations (UN, UNESCO, UNICEF, etc.). A variety of mass media techniques, including public relations, media events, and advertising campaigns, have been used to gain public support for, and involvement in, a broad range of issues. For example, successful campaigns have been waged to help alleviate hunger in Somalia, to promote family planning in developing countries, to encourage breast feeding worldwide, and to reduce drug and tobacco abuse in western countries. Furthermore, indications are that the impact of media on public opinion in the former Yugoslavia has been significant during the past several years. 15/ These latter two activities are financed by USAID.

Social Benefit Programs 2.21 Several income support and poverty prevention programs, including unemployment benefits, social assistance and social insurance systems, are already in place. The financial viability of these systems -- in particular, the social assistance and social insurance systems -- is being strained as the demand for assistance increases and the contribution base shrinks. There is an immediate need to launch preparatory activities to make social benefit programs more equitable, more efficient, and more financially sustainable in the new economic context. Social Assistance 2.22 The decline in economic activity and its potentially adverse impact on household welfare led the Borrower in 1992 to establish a means-tested social assistance system.'6 The program has many positive attributes. It has delivered social assistance benefits to a rapidly increasing number of clients. The number of beneficiary households has increased dramatically, from 9,000 in 1992 to nearly 50,000 in 1994. The program has also established social minima (para. 2.23), which take into account household assets, and has attempted to maintain work incentives in the system. However, an analysis of the social assistance system suggests that the program could benefit from improvements in five areas: (a) Fiscal solvency. Existing benefit levels and eligibility criteria, which provide too much for too many recipients, have contributed to the fiscal unsustainability of the program. In September 1994, the Borrower was two months in arrears in making social assistance benefit payments. (b) Work incentives. The program contains disincentives to work. Benefit levels are too high and initial earnings from work are effectively taxed at 100 percent. (c) Equity. Households are not treated equitably in the system. The current social minima do not accurately reflect the different consumption needs of different households. (d) Program integration. The system is not well integrated with other social welfare programs. Parallel programs such as child allowances pursue similar objectives through different means, and are not adequately reflected in the design of social assistance. (e) Targeting effectiveness. The use of an average, rather than a minimum, consumption basket as the basis for social assistance eligibility makes the social assistance program ineffective in targeting the very poor. The basket is not adjusted for non-food or minimum nutritional requirements, nor for rural/urban or regional price differences. 16/ See Annex IV for a detailed description of the social assistance program.
 9 2.23 To transform the social welfare program into a system that equitably and efficiently targets the poor, the Borrower needs to establish a poverty line based on a minimum consumption basket. This poverty line could be the basic foundation for: (a) identifying and targeting the poorest households in the economy and thereby improving equity; (b) establishing social assistance minimum benefits and making them consistent across cash benefit systems; and (c) maintaining work incentives in the program that are critical to the functioning of a market economy. 2.24 Identification of the poor, and policy changes to improve efficiency and equity within the system, can only have the desired impact if responsible Government institutions have the administrative and management skills to effectively deliver benefits to the poor. In the past, Social Assistance Offices served as counseling centers for the "socially handicapped population". The means-tested social assistance program was superimposed on this system without any significant accompanying changes in the staffing, administrative capacity, information flows, enforcement mechanisms and physical capital requirements of the system. Although the staff to client ratio for the whole program has decreased from 1/35 to 1/77, it remains reasonable by OECD standards. Benefits 5.1 The major benefit expected from the proposed project would be to maintain public acceptance of the country's economic reform program, thus helping ensure the sustainability of the reform program. In addition, labor redeployment activities supported by the project would help reduce public budgetary outlays and increase national output by moving workers from jobs where they are not productive, and receive public subsidies, to jobs where they are more productive. The employment effect of some labor redeployment programs (i.e. training) may be reduced to some extent if workers who benefit from the programs displace other workers. However, even in these cases, the programs should contribute to increased productivity. The project would also help restore long-run fiscal balance by improving tax collections and by establishing a more equitable, efficient, and affordable basis for pensions and social assistance. B. Risks 5.2 The principal risk associated with the proposed project is that a failure to impose a hard budget constraint could permit further delays in real restructuring of the largest loss-making enterprises, including needed labor shedding, thereby undermining the basis for the project. The proposed FESAC and follow-up policy oversight expected under subsequent operations would reduce this risk to an acceptable level. Moreover, because the project is viewed by Government authorities as a pre-requisite to effective enterprise reform, the project itself would help to mitigate this risk. However, in the event that there are substantial delays or changes in the FESAC that affect the special restructuring program, the configuration of the project may need to be reconsidered. Finally, the implementation capacity of some of the agencies involved is weak. The project addresses this issue by providing technical assistance and requiring the agencies to add small numbers of staff to support project implementation.

Eligibility and Benefits The social assistance program delivers benefits to individuals falling below established social minima. The programs covers the employed, the unemployed and pensioners. Individuals must register with the unemployment offices to be eligible for benefits. The social minima are established separately by employment category and are based on an 'average consumption' basket. The amount of benefits received by a household are equal to the difference between the individual's income and the social minima established for the employment status of the individual. So for example, the per capita social minimum is set at 25% average wage for the employed, 20% of average wage for pensioners and 15% of average wage for the unemployed.' 2. Equity and Efficiency In principle, in order to maintain work incentives, minimum wages should exceed minimum unemployment benefits and these in turn should be greater than the 'poverty line'. In Macedonia minimum wages (44% of average wage) are greater than unemployment benefits (36% of average wage). But the social assistance minimum varies by household size and employment category. For a four member household headed by an employed individual the social assistance minimum is 100% of average wage. The higher social assistance minimum for the employed was actually instituted to maintain work incentives in the sytem. Indeed, transfers to the employed exceed transfers to any other household category, giving individuals an incentive to work. But there are two critical problems with the current incentive system. (d) Costs of services: LRF reimbursement to local agencies providing services to workers would be based on the average unit cost of providing services to a worker times the number of workers actually participating in the programs. Exceptions would be made in the case of incubator development where a SOE could be reimbursed for mobilization costs as agreed between the SOE and Privatization Agency, and reimbursement for community development plans which would be on a lump sum basis. There is a cap of 25 percent of LRF expenditures on small business assistance and incubator services, unless otherwise agreed with the Bank. (e) Evaluation of services: Service providers would be required to provide job placement information for all participants who receive services (see special note on follow-up requirements on retraining services on the following page). (f) Mobility: Labor mobility among displaced workers would be encouraged under the project. Workers in communities qualifying for assistance under the Fund would be eligible for services in their communities or in other communities receiving assistance under the Fund. To support this initiative, the EAG would collect and disseminate information on services available through the Fund throughout the country. Employment and counseling services would include information on national job vacancies and associated training opportunities. The Fund could support relocation costs for displaced workers to move to localities where suitable jobs are available. It could also support transportation for participants in training programs and public works programs.

doc.abstracts: The success of Macedonia's economic reform program will depend upon whether the Borrower can deal effectively with the social dimensions of reform. The Social Reform and Technical Assistance Project will support the Borrower's reform program by: (a) facilitating the restructuring of socially owned enterprises through actions to reduce the individual and community impacts of worker dislocation, (b) improving the delivery of social benefits and the collection of payroll contributions for social benefits, (c) improving public awareness of the rationale for reform policies, and (d) supporting the continuing implementation of the enterprise restructuring program.
